verses.text: The elder, to the chosen lady and to her children, whom I truly love, and not only I, but also all who have known the truth.
verses.comment: The 'chosen lady' is often understood either as a church or as a Christian woman and her family. The theme of truth and love is key in Johannine writings.

verses.text: Because of the truth which lives in us and will be with us forever.
verses.comment: The promise of truth enduring forever emphasizes the indwelling of the Spirit (see John 14:16), indicating both a personal and communal abiding.

verses.text: Grace, mercy, and peace will be with us, from God the Father and from Jesus Christ, the Son of the Father, in truth and love.
verses.comment: The threefold blessing—grace, mercy, and peace—indicates fullness of Christian life, highlighting the union between the Father and the Son, a high Christology (see John’s prologue John 1:1-3).

verses.text: I rejoiced greatly to find some of your children walking in the truth, just as we were commanded by the Father.
verses.comment: Obedience to the command of the Father is reiteration of the theme of fidelity to apostolic teaching. Spiritual children walking in truth reflects the ongoing generational faithfulness.

verses.text: And now I ask you, dear lady—not as though I am writing a new commandment, but one we have had from the beginning—that we love one another.
verses.comment: The command to love one another echoes Jesus’ own words and highlights continuity with foundational teachings. 'From the beginning' hints at apostolic tradition handed on consistently.

verses.text: And this is love: that we walk according to his commandments. This is the commandment, just as you have heard from the beginning, that you should walk in it.
verses.comment: True love is inseparable from obedience. Walking in the commandments from the start signals the importance of handed-down tradition in living out the faith.

verses.text: For many deceivers have gone out into the world, those who do not confess Jesus Christ coming in the flesh. Such a one is the deceiver and the antichrist.
verses.comment: Confessing Jesus Christ ‘coming in the flesh’ reaffirms the incarnation, a distinguishing mark from early heresies. The reference to antichrist is a warning against deviations from authentic teaching.

verses.text: Watch yourselves, so that you do not lose what we have worked for, but may win a full reward.
verses.comment: The exhortation to vigilance implies that perseverance is necessary for attaining the fullness of reward. The text points to cooperation with grace over time.

verses.text: Everyone who goes ahead and does not remain in the teaching of Christ does not have God; whoever abides in the teaching has both the Father and the Son.
verses.comment: Remaining in the teaching—apostolic doctrine—is essential for full communion with God. This strongly supports the importance of an unbroken, apostolic tradition.

verses.text: If anyone comes to you and does not bring this teaching, do not welcome him into your house or give him any greeting,
verses.comment: Refusal of hospitality to false teachers stresses the need for boundaries in protecting the integrity of the faith community. The primacy of correct doctrine is evident.

verses.text: for whoever greets him shares in his wicked works.
verses.comment: Partnership in error is seen as serious—fellowship with teaching contrary to apostolic faith is equated with evil. Community discipline is vital.

verses.text: Although I have much to write to you, I would rather not use paper and ink. Instead, I hope to come to you and speak face to face, so that our joy may be complete.
verses.comment: Direct, personal fellowship is the intended norm for apostolic communication, reflecting the high value given to communal gathering and shared joy.

verses.text: The children of your chosen sister greet you.
verses.comment: Greetings from the ‘chosen sister’s children’ suggest interconnected Christian communities, united in mutual charity and faith.
